nova-e-text--color-inherit"><strong>Abstract</strong></div><div class="nova-e-text nova-e-text--size-m nova-e-text--family-sans-serif nova-e-text--spacing-auto nova-e-text--color-inherit">This trans-disciplinary study assesses total external environmental and health costs of modern agriculture in the UK. A wide range of datasets have been analysed to assess cost distribution across sectors. We calculate the annual total external costs of UK agriculture in 1996 to be £2343 m (range for 1990–1996: £1149–3907 m), equivalent to £208/ha of arable and permanent pasture. Significant costs arise from contamination of drinking water with pesticides (£120 m/year), nitrate (£16 m), Cryptosporidium (£23 m) and phosphate and soil (£55 m), from damage to wildlife, habitats, hedgerows and drystone walls (£125 m), from emissions of gases (£1113 m), from soil erosion and organic carbon losses (£106 m), from food poisoning (£169 m), and from bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE) (£607 m). This study has only estimated those externalities that give rise to financial costs, and so is likely to underestimate the total negative impacts of modern agriculture. These data help to identify policy priorities, particularly over the most efficient way to internalise these external costs into prices. This would imply a redirection of public subsidies towards encouraging those positive externalities under-provided in the market place, combined with a mix of advisory and institutional mechanisms, regulatory and legal measures, and economic instruments to correct negative externalities. Further work examining the marginal costs and benefits of UK agriculture would help to inform future policy development.</div></div><div class="signup-promo-with-stats received in revised form 12 May 2000; accepted 30 June 2000</div><div class="t m0 x0 h8 y17 ff3 fs5 fc0 sc0 ls2">Abstract</div><div class="t m0 x1a h9 y18 ff1 fs5 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsc">This trans-disciplinary study assesses total external environmental and health costs of</div><div class="t m0 x0 h9 y19 ff1 fs5 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsd">modern agriculture in the UK. A wide range of datasets have been analysed to assess cost</div><div class="t m0 x0 h9 y1a ff1 fs5 fc0 sc0 ls2 wse">distribution across sectors. We calculate the annual total external costs of UK agriculture in</div><div class="t m0 x0 h9 y1b ff1 fs5 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsf">1996 to be £2343 m (range for 1990±1996: £1149±3907 m), equivalent to £208/ha of arable and</div><div class="t m0 x0 h9 y1c ff1 fs5 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws10">permanent pasture. Signi®cant costs arise from contamination of drinking water with pesti-</div><div class="t m0 x0 h9 y1d ff1 fs5 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws11">cides (£120 m/year), nitrate (£16 m), <span class="ff2 ws12">Cryptosporidium </span><span class="ws13">(£23 m) and phosphate and soil (£55 m),</span></div><div class="t m0 x0 h9 y1e ff1 fs5 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws14">from damage to wildlife, habitats, hedgerows and drystone walls (£125 m), from emissions of</div><div class="t m0 x0 h9 y1f ff1 fs5 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws15">gases (£1113 m), from soil erosion and organic carbon losses (£106 m), from food poisoning</div><div class="t m0 x0 h9 y20 ff1 fs5 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws16">(£169 m), and from bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE) (£607 m). This study has only</div><div class="t m0 x0 h9 y21 ff1 fs5 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws17">estimated those externalities that give rise to ®nancial costs, and so is likely to underestimate</div><div class="t m0 x0 h9 y22 ff1 fs5 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws18">the total negative impacts of modern agriculture. These data help to identify policy priorities,</div><div class="t m0 x0 h9 y23 ff1 fs5 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws19">particularly over the most ecient way to internalise these external costs into prices. This</div><div class="t m0 x0 h9 y24 ff1 fs5 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws18">would imply a redirection of public subsidies towards encouraging those positive externalities</div><div class="t m0 x0 h9 y25 ff1 fs5 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws1a">under-provided in the market place, combined with a mix of advisory and institutional</div><div class="t m0 x0 h9 y26 ff1 fs5 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws1b">mechanisms, regulatory and legal measures, and economic instruments to correct negative</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y27 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws1c">0308-521X/00/$ - see front matter <span class="ff4 ls0">#</span>2000 Elsevier Science Ltd. Fax: +44-1206-87-34-16.</div><div class="t m0 x1e h7 y2c ff2 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws1f">E-mail address: <span class="ff1 wsa">jpretty@essex.ac.uk (J.N. Pretty).</span></div></div><div class="pi" data-data="{&quot;ctm&quot;:[1.801471,0.000000,0.000000,1.801471,0.000000,0.000000]}"></div></div>        </div>            <div class="pdf-page-separator"></div>        <div class="pdf-viewer-page">            <div id="pf2" class="pf w0 h0" data-page-no="2"><div class="pc pc2 w0 h0"><div class="bi x0 y2d w2 ha lazyload" data-bg="profile/Jules_Pretty/publication/222549141/viewer/AS:592440796921856@1518260301360/background/2.png" style="background-size: contain;"></div><div class="t m0 x0 h9 y2e ff1 fs5 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws21">externalities. Further work examining the marginal costs and bene®ts of UK agriculture would</div><div class="t m0 x0 h9 y2f ff1 fs5 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws22">help to inform future policy development. <span class="ff4 ls3">#</span><span class="ws23">2000 Elsevier Science Ltd. All rights reserved.</span></div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y30 ff2 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws24">Keywords: <span class="ff1 ws25">Externalities; Agriculture; Water pollution; Health; Pesticides; Biodiversity; Food poisoning;</span></div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y31 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2">Policies</div><div class="t m0 x0 hb y32 ff3 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws26">1. De®nition and concept of<span class="_ _1"> </span>externalities</div><div class="t m0 x1e hc y33 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws27">Farmers in the UK have been highly successful at increasing food production in</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y34 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws28">the 20th century. Compared with 1950, per hectare yields of wheat, barley,<span class="_ _0"> </span>potatoes</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y35 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws29">and sugar beet have tripled, while milk yields per cow have more<span class="_ _0"> </span>than doubled. But</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y36 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws2a">these remarkable achievements have also brought costly environmental, healt<span class="_ _2"></span>h and</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y37 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws2b">social problems (Conway and Pretty, 1991; Pretty, 1995, 1998; Mason, 1996; EEA,</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y38 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws2c">1998; Krebs et al., 1999).</div><div class="t m0 x1e hc y39 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws28">Most economic activities aect the environment, either through the use of natural</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y3a ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws2d">resources as an input or by using the `clean&apos; environment as a sink for pollution. The</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y3b ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws2b">costs of using the environment in this way are called externalities, because they are</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y3c ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws2e">side eects of the economic activity and their costs are not part of the prices paid by</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y3d ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws2f">producers or consumers. When such externalities are not included in prices, they</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y3e ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws30">distort the market by encouraging activities that are costly to society even if the</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y3f ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws31">private bene®ts are substantial (Baumol and Oates, 1988; Pearce and Turner, 1990;</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y40 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws32">Lewis, 1996; EEA, 1998; Brouwer, 1999; Pretty et al., 1999).</div><div class="t m0 x1e hc y41 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws33">An externality is any action that aects the welfare of or opportunities<span class="_ _0"> </span>available to</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y42 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws34">an individual or group without direct payment or compensation, and may be posi-</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y43 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws35">tive or negative. The types of externalities encountered in the agricultural sector</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y44 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws36">have ®ve features: (1) their costs are often neglected; (2) they often occur<span class="_ _0"> </span>with a time</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y45 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws37">lag; (3) they often damage groups whose interests are not represented; (4) the iden-</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y46 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws38">tity of the producer of the externality is not always known; and (5) they<span class="_ _0"> </span>result in</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y47 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws32">sub-optimal economic and policy solutions.</div><div class="t m0 x0 hb y48 ff3 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws26">2. Costing negative agricult<span class="_ _2"></span>ural externalities</div><div class="t m0 x1e hc y49 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws39">Although several attempts have been made to put a cost on some<span class="_ _0"> </span>of the pollution</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y4a ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws3a">arising from agriculture in the USA and Europe, it has proven dicult to do. First,</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y4b ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws3b">it is necessary to know about the value of nature&apos;s goods and services, and what</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y4c ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws3c">happens when these are lost. The current system of economic calculations grossly</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y4d ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws3d">underestimates the current and future value of natural capital (Abramovitz, 1997;</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y4e ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws3e">Costanza et al., 1997; Daily, 1997).</div><div class="t m0 x1e hc y4f ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws36">Second is the diculty of putting a value on non-market goods. How do we value,</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y50 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws3f">for example, skylarks singing on a summer&apos;s day, or a landscape with<span class="_ _1"> </span>hedgerows</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y51 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws40">and trees, or a watershed producing clean water? Environmental economists have</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y52 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws41">developed methods for assessing people&apos;s stated preferences for environmental</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y53 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws42">goods through hypothetical markets (Willis et al., 1993; Hanley et al., 1998;</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y54 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws43">114 <span class="ff2 ws44">J.N. Pretty et al.<span class="_ _2"> </span>/ Agricultural Systems 65 (2000) 113±136</span></div></div><div class="pi" data-data="{&quot;ctm&quot;:[1.801471,0.000000,0.000000,1.801471,0.000000,0.000000]}"></div></div>        </div>            <div class="pdf-page-separator"></div>        <div class="pdf-viewer-page">            <div id="pf3" class="pf w0 h0" data-page-no="3"><div class="pc pc3 w0 h0"><div class="bi x0 y55 w3 ha lazyload" data-bg="profile/Jules_Pretty/publication/222549141/viewer/AS:592440796921856@1518260301360/background/3.png" style="background-size: contain;"></div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y56 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws45">Brouwer, 1999). The value of nature&apos;s goods and services is represented to an extent</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y57 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws46">by people&apos;s willingness-to-pay (WTP) for them, and this permits<span class="_ _0"> </span>estimation of ben-</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y58 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws47">e®ts foregone, the correct economic welfare measure. However, in view of scient<span class="_ _2"></span>i®c</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y59 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws48">and economic uncertainties about many agriculturally related problems, we use</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y5a ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws49">®nancial costs to help to overcome uncertainties with valuation. This restricts the</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y5b ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4a">range of impacts we are able to value, though it can help to overcome the problem</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y5c ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4b">of scienti®c uncertainty where expenditure is incurred in relation to a speci®c agri-</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y5d ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4c">cultural issue. This approach does not, therefore, actually value the externality, but</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y5e ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws3a">uses as a proxy the expenditure which society incurs in dealing with that externality</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y5f ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws32">(Bailey et al., 1999; Hanley and Oglethorpe, 1999; Hill and Crabtree, 2000).</div><div class="t m0 x1e hc y60 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4d">There have been several studies on the external costs of modern agriculture in</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y61 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws32">Germany, Netherlands, UK and the USA (Pimentel et al., 1992, 1995; Evans, 1995,</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y62 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4e">1996; Steiner et al., 1995; Davison et al., 1996; Fleischer and Waibel, 1998; Waibel</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y63 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4f">and Fleischer, 1998; Bailey et al., 1999; Ribaudo et al., 1999). These suggest that</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y64 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws50">total external costs are some $81±117/ha of arable and permanent pasture in Ger-</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y65 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws51">many (only pesticides and gaseous emissions costed) and the<span class="_ _0"> </span>USA, rising to $112±</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y66 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws52">274 for arable land only (Pretty et al., 2000). For several reasons, however, these</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y67 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws53">data are not wholly comparable in their original form, and method<span class="_ _2"></span>ological concerns</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y68 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws36">have been raised about some studies (Bowles and Webster, 1995; Crosson, 1995; van</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y69 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws32">der Bijl and Bleumink, 1997; Pearce and Tinch, 1998)</div><div class="t m3 x1f hd y6a ff1 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2">1</div><div class="t m0 x20 hc y6b ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2">.</div><div class="t m0 x1e hc y6c ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws54">The need for estimates of externality costs occurs at two levels. The ®rst is the level</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y6d ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws55">at which national and international policy strategies are developed. Here, there is</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y6e ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws56">need for estimates of total costs, both overall and by type of externality. These esti-</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y6f ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws28">mates provide a broad guide for policy emphases. Areas in which costs appear to be</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y70 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws3a">greatest are then obvious candidates for policy emphases and further analyses.</div><div class="t m0 x1e hc y71 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws57">The second level is that of particular policies, programmes, or project<span class="_ _2"></span>s. Here,</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y72 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws58">estimates of social costs and bene®ts, in the form of cost-bene®t or cost-eectiveness</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y73 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws59">studies, can help guide decisions, for example, about which agri-environmental</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y74 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws5a">initiatives are best suited to reducing externalities. Hanley et al. (1999)</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y75 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws5b">recently reviewed and summarised a dozen such cost-bene®t studies of<span class="_ _1"> </span>UK agri-</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y76 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4b">environmental schemes. Such studies are extremely useful in helping<span class="_ _0"> </span>to judge whe-</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y77 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws52">ther the costs associated with particular policies or program<span class="_ _2"></span>mes are warranted in</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y78 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws5c">terms of their social bene®ts. However, as Whitby (2000) has recently noted, most</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y79 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws5d">evaluations of UK agri-environmental schemes have not actually been able to value</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y7a ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws5e">bene®ts at the margin. In other words, even if a scheme has produced more social</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y7b ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws5f">bene®ts than costs in a particular area, it is still unknown how reducing or expand-</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y7c ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws60">ing the scheme would aect bene®ts and costs. Oglethorpe et al. (2000) have recently</div><div class="t m2 x1e h5 y7d ff1 fs3 fc0 sc0 ls2">1</div><div class="t m0 x21 h7 y7e ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws61">Some critiques of earlier studies on externalities have noted that several eects could not be assessed</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y7f ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws62">in monetary terms, whilst others have appeared to be more arbitrary (e.g. the cost of bird deaths in the</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y80 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws63">USA ($2 billion) is arrived at by multiplying 67 million losses by $30 a bird; Pimentel et al., 1992). The</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y81 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws64">Davison et al. (1996) study on Netherlands agriculture was even more arbitrary, as it added the costs</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y82 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws9">farmers would incur to reach stated policy objectives, and these were based on predicted yield<span class="_ _3"> </span>reductions</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y83 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws65">of 10±25% arising from neither cheap nor preferable technologies, which led to a large overestimate of</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y84 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws66">environmental damage (c.f. van der Bijl and Bleumink, 1997).</div><div class="t m0 x18 h7 y85 ff2 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws44">J.N. Pretty et al.<span class="_ _2"> </span>/ Agricultural Systems 65 (2000) 113±136<span class="_ _4"> </span><span class="ff1">115</span></div></div><div class="pi" data-data="{&quot;ctm&quot;:[1.801471,0.000000,0.000000,1.801471,0.000000,0.000000]}"></div></div>        </div>            <div class="pdf-page-separator"></div>        <div class="pdf-viewer-page">            <div id="pf4" class="pf w0 h0" data-page-no="4"><div class="pc pc4 w0 h0"><div class="t m0 x0 hc y56 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws37">demonstrated how a true marginal analysis can be used to aid policy<span class="_ _0"> </span>development,</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y57 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws3a">using the example of a case study in Scotland.</div><div class="t m0 x1e hc y58 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws67">This study is focused on information for policies at the ®rst level, where broad</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y59 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws68">policy strategies are developed. We address the policy implications of this study</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y5a ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws69">brie¯y at the end of the article, and in more depth in a companion article (Pretty et</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y5b ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws6a">al., 2000). There is need for better information at both levels, however,<span class="_ _1"> </span>to guide</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y5c ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws6b">eectively the future rounds of agricultural policy reform in the UK, throughout</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y5d ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws5d">Europe, and elsewhere in industrialised countries.</div><div class="t m0 x0 hb y60 ff3 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws6c">3. Framework for asses<span class="_ _2"></span>sing the negative externalities of UK agriculture</div><div class="t m0 x1e hc y62 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws68">In this study, we use a framework of seven cost categories to assess the total</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y63 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws37">environmental and health costs of UK agriculture. Two types of damage cost have</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y64 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws6d">been estimated: (1) the treatment or prevention costs (those incurred to clean up<span class="_ _3"> </span>the</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y65 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws5d">environment and restore human health to comply with legislation or to return these</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y66 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws26">to an undamaged state); and (2) the administration an<span class="_ _2"></span>d monitoring costs (those</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y67 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws6e">incurred by public authorities and agencies for monitoring environmental, food and</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y68 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws2f">health parameters). We have estimated only those externalities which give rise to</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y69 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws56">®nancial costs.</div><div class="t m0 x1e hc y86 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws34">This framework includes only external costs, i.e. the costs incurred by the rest of</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y87 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4e">society for the actions of farmers. Additional private costs borne by farmers them-</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y88 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws6f">selves are not included, such as from increased pest or weed resistance from the</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y89 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws70">overuse of pesticides, or for training in the use, storage and disposal of pesticides.</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y8a ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws71">However, there remain distributional problems, e.g. insect outb<span class="_ _2"></span>reaks arising from</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y8b ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws56">pesticide overuse can aect all farmers, even those not using pesticides.</div><div class="t m0 x1e hc y8c ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws72">We have also not yet measured the positive externalities (the bene®cial side-<span class="_ _2"></span>eects)</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y8d ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws73">created by farming and encouraged by certain policies (OECD, 1997a; Lobley and</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y8e ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws74">Potter, 1998; Hanley and Oglethorpe, 1999; van Huyelenbroek and Whitby, 1999;</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y8f ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws75">Darling and Topp, 2000). These include: landscape and aesthetic value;<span class="_ _0"> </span>recreation</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y90 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws40">and amenity; water accumulation and supply; nutrient recycling and ®xation; soil</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y91 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws76">formation; wildlife, including agriculturally bene®cial orga<span class="_ _2"></span>nisms; storm protection</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y92 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws77">and ¯ood control; and carbon sequestration by trees and soils.<span class="_ _3"> </span>These are likely to be</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y93 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws32">substantial (Daily, 1997; Smith et al., 1998; Hanley and Oglethorpe, 1999).</div><div class="t m0 x1e hc y94 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws78">Table 1 summarises the annual total external environmental and health costs of</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y95 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws60">UK agriculture. A conservative estimate puts these at £2343 m for 1996 alone (range</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y96 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws79">for 1990±1996: £1149±3907 m). These per hectare costs are substantially greater</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y61 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws93">than those estimated in other studies, probably re¯ecting the more comprehens<span class="_ _2"></span>ive</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y62 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws3c">nature of the framework and range of impacts measured. Nonetheless, we believe</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y63 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws96">them to be a conservative estimate of the true costs.</div><div class="t m0 x0 hb y66 ff3 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws97">4. Why estimates of externalities a<span class="_ _2"></span>re likely to be conservative</div><div class="t m0 x1e hc y68 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws98">This study attempts to estimate the total external costs of UK agriculture.</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y69 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws7c">Given the multifaceted and dynamic nature of agriculture and its impact on envir-</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y86 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws99">onment and human health, we have had to make many assumptions about the</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y87 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws9a">data. In most cases, these result in conservative estimates of costs, though<span class="_ _1"> </span>one</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y88 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws9b">(the BSE crisis) has in¯ated the costs above the long-term<span class="_ _0"> </span>annual averages, assum-</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y89 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws9c">ing that the expected eradication of BSE does occur.</div><div class="t m0 x1a hc y8b ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws45">1.<span class="_ _1"> </span>Some costs are known to be substantial underestimates<span class="_ _3"> </span>(e.g. acute and ch<span class="_ _2"></span>ronic</div><div class="t m0 x1 hc y8c ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4c">pesticide poisoning of humans; monitoring costs; eutrophication of reservoirs;</div><div class="t m0 x1 hc y8d ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws29">restoration of all hedgerow losses), to be limited to certain geographic areas of</div><div class="t m0 x1 hc y8e ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws9d">the UK (water company returns are for England and Wales only), or currently</div><div class="t m0 x1 hc y8f ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws50">cannot be calculated (e.g. dredging to maintain navigable water; ¯ood defen-</div><div class="t m0 x1 hc y90 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws5d">ces; marine eutrophication; poisoning of domestic pets).</div><div class="t m0 x1a hc y91 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws60">2.<span class="_ _1"> </span>We do not generally calculate the costs of returning the environment or human</div><div class="t m0 x1 hc y92 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws74">health to pristine conditions. Pesticides in drinking water, for exampl<span class="_ _2"></span>e, must</div><div class="t m0 x1 hc y93 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws51">not exceed a maximum of 0.5 <span class="ff5 ws9e">m</span>g/l for all compounds. Yet BSE represents an</div><div class="t m0 x1 hc y94 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws7d">example of the cost of complete eradication of a problem. If<span class="_ _3"> </span>all cost categories</div><div class="t m0 x1 hc y95 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws9f">were estimated for such restoration, then the total externalities would be sub-</div><div class="t m0 x1 hc y96 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws5d">stantially greater than estimated in this study.</div><div class="t m0 x1a hc y97 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws46">3.<span class="_ _1"> </span>Treatment and prevention costs may be underestimates of the<span class="_ _0"> </span>true costs. This</div><div class="t m0 x1 hc yd9 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsa0">signi®cantly underestimates the true costs of biodiversity loss, since in most</div><div class="t m0 x1 hc y98 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsa1">cases species and habitat plans aim to restore only a small proportion of pre-</div><div class="t m0 x1 hc y99 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsa2">vious biodiversity losses. Agriculture&apos;s eect on biodiversity is estimated</div><div class="t m0 x1 hc y9a ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws27">according to the cost of implementing plans to return species and habitats to</div><div class="t m0 x1 hc y9b ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4e">acceptable levels for society (after accounting for non-agricultural impac<span class="_ _2"></span>ts on</div><div class="t m0 x1 hc y9c ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsa3">biodiversity). But this underestimates the non-user values, which may be sub-</div><div class="t m0 x1 hc y9d ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws39">stantial. We have not estimated people&apos;s WTP for option values (the option of</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y54 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws43">118 <span class="ff2 ws44">J.N. Pretty et al.<span class="_ _2"> </span>/ Agricultural Systems 65 (2000) 113±136</span></div></div><div class="pi" data-data="{&quot;ctm&quot;:[1.801471,0.000000,0.000000,1.801471,0.000000,0.000000]}"></div></div>        </div>            <div class="pdf-page-separator"></div>        <div class="pdf-viewer-page">            <div id="pf7" class="pf w0 h0" data-page-no="7"><div class="pc pc7 w0 h0"><div class="t m0 x1 hc y56 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws3f">enjoying something in the future); bequest values (ensuring that descendants</div><div class="t m0 x1 hc y57 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws70">will be able to derive value); and existence values (the value of knowing that</div><div class="t m0 x1 hc y58 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsa4">something simply exists). In general, this study accounts for use values, and</div><div class="t m0 x1 hc y59 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws34">underestimates the rest (e.g. archaeological remains many have high existence</div><div class="t m0 x1 hc y5a ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsa1">value to some people, yet many have been destroyed by cultivation). In addi-</div><div class="t m0 x1 hc y5b ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsa5">tion, by focusing on costs, this study underestimates how much people might</div><div class="t m0 x1 hc y5c ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsa6">be willing to pay to see positive externalities created (c.f. Willis et al., 1993;</div><div class="t m0 x1 hc y5d ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws32">Darling and Topp, 2000).</div><div class="t m0 x1a hc y5e ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsa7">4. Thi<span class="_ _2"></span>s study does not account for time lags between the cause of a problem</div><div class="t m0 x1 hc y5f ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsa8">and its expression as a cost. Some costs incurred in the 1990s may have</div><div class="t m0 x1 hc y60 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsa9">arisen from activities or technologies long since stopped (e.g. organochlorine</div><div class="t m0 x1 hc y61 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsaa">residues carried into rivers in Cornwall by eroded soil long after banned from</div><div class="t m0 x1 hc y62 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsa4">use Ð RCEP, 1996). Others may not yet be expressed (e.g. accurate predic-</div><div class="t m0 x1 hc y63 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsab">tions about the future number of cases of new variant Creutzveldt-Jakob</div><div class="t m0 x1 hc y64 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsac">Disease [nvCJD] are impossible; and the role of pesticides as endocrine</div><div class="t m0 x1 hc y65 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws9e">disruptors).</div><div class="t m0 x1a hc y66 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4b">5.<span class="_ _1"> </span>We have not included the cost of research in this study, as it is impossible to</div><div class="t m0 x1 hc y67 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws5b">disaggregate research budgets on the basis of allocations for addressing the</div><div class="t m0 x1 hc y68 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws56">problems of negative externalities.</div><div class="t m0 x1a hc y69 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsad">6.<span class="_ _1"> </span>We do not include the very substantial public subsidy for farming (£3 billion</div><div class="t m0 x1 hc y86 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsae">annually during the 1990s), as there is no accepted relationship between pro-</div><div class="t m0 x1 hc y87 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsaf">vision of subsidies and creation of negative externalities. Subsidies are a</div><div class="t m0 x1 hc y88 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws2e">transfer from taxpayers to farmers (whether or not external costs are induced).</div><div class="t m0 x1 hc y89 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsb0">Some of this support is used to create positive bene®ts, directly through agri-</div><div class="t m0 x1 hc y8a ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsb1">environmental programmes (approximately £100 m annually in the UK to the</div><div class="t m0 x1 hc y8b ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws46">late 1990s, and rising under CAP reforms), and the removal of public support</div><div class="t m0 x1 hc y8c ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsb2">could, indeed, lead to greater negative externalities, such as via farm amalga-</div><div class="t m0 x1 hc y8d ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws3a">mation, removal of hedgerows, and increased pesticide use.</div><div class="t m0 x1a hc y8e ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsb0">7.<span class="_ _1"> </span>This study has sought to estimate only those costs arising from the farm. We</div><div class="t m0 x1 hc y8f ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsb3">have not included the many environmental and social costs associated with</div><div class="t m0 x1 hc y90 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws8f">getting food from the farm gate to consumers&apos; plates. Transport externalities</div><div class="t m0 x1 hc y91 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws72">are likely to be signi®cant (Raven and Lang, 1995; ECMT, 1998). We have<span class="_ _3"> </span>also</div><div class="t m0 x1 hc y92 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws67">not included an assessment of the costs caused by modern farming on rural</div><div class="t m0 x1 hc y93 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws9e">communities.</div><div class="t m0 x0 hb y96 ff3 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws7a">5. The key policy question is, are there types of agri-</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y9a ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsc5">culture that could substantially reduce these costs? We also do not asses<span class="_ _2"></span>s all external</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y9b ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws3c">costs, such as the avoidance costs of water consumers switching<span class="_ _0"> </span>to bottl<span class="_ _2"></span>ed water.</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y9c ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws26">Companies incur both capital and operating expenditure for water quality treat-</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y9d ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsc6">ment. These costs would be much</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y58 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws3a">greater if the policy goal were complete removal of all residues/contaminants.</div><div class="t m0 x0 hf y5a ff2 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsc8">5.1.1.<span class="_ _1"> </span>Pesticides in sources of drinking water (1a)</div><div class="t m0 x1e hc y5b ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsc9">Annual capital expenditure by water companies on pesticide removal between</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y5c ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsca">1992 and 1997 was £124.9 m/year after depreciation (at 1996 prices). Operating</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y5d ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wscb">expenditure by the 28 companies is generally much higher in the east<span class="_ _0"> </span>of England,</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y5e ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wscc">but is not always reported separately. Based on returns to Ofwat, we estimate</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y5f ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsa0">annual operating costs for pesticide removal to be £9.5 m. As 8<span class="_ _2"></span>9% of pesticides</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y60 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsaa">(some 22.5 m kg) are applied in farming (BAA, 1998), the total pesticide costs aris-</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y61 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws3a">ing from farming are £119.6 m/year.</div><div class="t m0 x0 hf y63 ff2 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws5d">5.1.2.<span class="_ _1"> </span>Nitrate in sources of drinking water (1b)</div><div class="t m0 x1e hc y64 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws74">Nitrate enters drinking water sources from fertilisers and livestock<span class="_ _0"> </span>wastes, from</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y65 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wscd">mineralisation of organic nitrogen in the soil, from atmospheric depositions, and</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y66 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsce">from human sewage. Capital expenditure by water companies on nitrate removal</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y67 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wscf">between 1992 and 1997 was £18.8 m/year, and operating expenditures £1.7 m (both</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y68 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws31">are higher in the east). We estimate that 80% of nitrogen is from agricultural sour-</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y69 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws3e">ces, putting annual external costs at £16.4 m/year.</div><div class="t m0 x0 hf y87 ff2 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws2c">5.1.3.<span class="_ _1"> </span>Phosphate and soil in sources of drinking water (1c)</div><div class="t m0 x1e hc y88 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws78">Phosphate also contaminates water, with some 43% in water estimated to come</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y89 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws5d">from agriculture (29% from livestock; 14% from fertilizers), mostly attached to soil</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y8a ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws58">particles from eroded land, the remainder coming from point sources (human waste,</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y8b ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws54">detergents, industry; RCEP, 1996; EA, 1998a; EEA, 1998; Withers and Jarvis, 1998).</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y8c ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsab">Capital expenditure on both phosphate and soil particle removal was £68.8 m</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y8d ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wscf">between 1992 and 1997, with a further £4.3 m for operating expenditure.<span class="_ _3"> </span>Ass<span class="_ _2"></span>uming</div><div class="t m2 x1e h5 ydc ff1 fs3 fc0 sc0 ls2">2</div><div class="t m0 x21 h7 ydd ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsd0">The government&apos;s Oce of the Director General of Water Services sets industry price levels each ®ve</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 yde ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsd1">years, which determine both the maximum levels of water bills and speci®es investments in water quality</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 ydf ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsd2">treatment. During the 1990s, water industry undertook pesticide and nitrate removal schemes, resulting in</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 ye0 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsd3">the construction of 120 plants for pesticide removal and 30 for nitrate removal (Ofwat, 1998). Ofwat</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 ye1 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsd4">estimates that water companies will spend a further £600 m between 2000 and 2005 on capital expenditure</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 ye2 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsd5">alone due to continuing deterioration of `raw water&apos; quality due to all factors. Ofwat predicts capital</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 ye3 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws66">expenditure for pesticides to fall to £88 m/year at the end of the 1990s/early 2000s; and for nitrate to fall</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 ye4 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws83">to £8.3 m/year.</div><div class="t m0 x1e h7 ye5 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsd6">Although Ofwat has sought to standardise reporting, individual companies report water treatment costs</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 ye6 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsd7">in dierent ways. Most do distinguish treatment for pesticides, nitrate, <span class="ff2 ws1e">Cryptosporidium</span><span class="wsd8">, and several</span></div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 ye7 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsd9">metals (iron, manganese, lead). The remaining treatment costs for phosphorus, soil removal, arsenic and</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 ye8 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws86">other metals, appear under a category labelled `other&apos;. Of the 28 water companies in England and Wales,</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 ye9 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsda">three report no expenditure on treatment whatsoever; and a further three do not disaggregate treatment</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 yea ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsdb">costs, with all appearing under `other&apos;. Twenty companies report expenditure on removal of pesticides, 11</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 yeb ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsdc">on nitrates, and 10 on <span class="ff2 ws1e">Cryptosporidium</span>. It is impossible to tell from the records whether a stated zero</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 yec ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsdd">expenditure is actually zero, or whether this has been placed in the `other&apos; category. Using Ofwat and</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 yed ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsde">water companies&apos; returns, we estimate that 50% of expenditure under the `other&apos; category refers to</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 yee ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws61">removal of agriculturally related materials.</div><div class="t m0 x18 h7 yef ff2 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws44">J.N.
