The most important agricultural contaminant is <span class="ff2 ws9e">Cryp-</span></div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y5c ff2 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws9e">tosporidium<span class="ff1 wsa4">, a protozoan causing severe diarrhoeal illness. It is resistant to chlor-</span></div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y5d ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsa0">ination and can only be removed by ®ltration. Expenditure was low in<span class="_ _1"> </span>the early</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y5e ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws2a">1990s (£27.6 m for 1992±1997), but by the end of the 1990s had risen to £8 m/year</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y5f ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws34">(DETR, 1998e). Ofwat, however, has indicated that £66 m/year will<span class="_ _0"> </span>be required to</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y60 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws52">meet legal compliances. We take a low±mid range annual ®gure of £25 m.</div><div class="t m3 x2c hd yf0 ff1 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2">3</div><div class="t m0 x28 hc yf1 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws9e">Until</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc yf2 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws54">recently, it was assumed that all <span class="ff2 wsdf">Cryptosporidium </span><span class="wse0">arose from animals Ð low levels of</span></div><div class="t m0 x0 hc yf3 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws7b">infection are common in cattle, and there are no practicable measures for eradica-</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc yf4 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws73">tion. But recent research indicates that some strains occur only in humans,<span class="_ _0"> </span>and so</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc yf5 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws53">we assume that 90% of the treatment costs are agricultural externalities<span class="_ _2"></span>, i.e. £22.5 m</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc yf6 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wse1">(Kemp et al., 1995; Sturdee et al., 1998). Type 1 strains of <span class="ff2 wse2">Cryptosporidium </span><span class="ws9e">aect</span></div><div class="t m0 x0 hc yf7 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws37">only humans, whilst Type 2 aect both animals and humans, and may be found in</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc yf8 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws32">both livestock wastes and sewage (ENDS, 1999a, b).</div><div class="t m0 x0 hf yf9 ff2 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsc8">5.1.5.<span class="_ _1"> </span>Eutrophication and pollution incidents from agriculture (1e)</div><div class="t m0 x1e hc yfa ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws38">Farm wastes further disrupt water systems: cattle and pig slurry,<span class="_ _0"> </span>silage<span class="_ _0"> </span>euent<span class="_ _2"></span>,</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc yfb ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws32">dairy wastes that cause eutrophication, and toxic products (such as sheep dips) that</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc yfc ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws67">kill aquatic life. In each of 1996±1997, there were 31,000±32,000 repo<span class="_ _2"></span>rts of water</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc yfd ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsb0">pollution in England and Wales from all sources, of which about 20,000 were sub-</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc yfe ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wse3">stantiated (EA, 1998b). Agriculture accounted an average 2600 incidents per year</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc yff ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsb0">during the 1990s (of which about 50 are in Category 1, 250 in Category 2, 2300 in</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y100 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws93">Category 3). Using the costs incurred by the EA for restocking rivers with ®sh to</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y101 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws3a">restore them to their pre-incident condition, we estimate the total cost of these<span class="_ _3"> </span>inci-</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y102 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsbe">dents to be £1.14±2.35 m/year.</div><div class="t m3 x25 hd y103 ff1 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2">4</div><div class="t m2 x1e h5 ydc ff1 fs3 fc0 sc0 ls2">3</div><div class="t m0 x21 h7 ydd ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 wse4">Expenditure on <span class="ff2 wse5">Cryptosporidium </span><span class="wse6">removal is likely to grow: Ofwat assumes that some £1000 m will be</span></div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 yde ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 wse7">invested on improved ®ltration and for <span class="ff2 wse8">Cryptosporidium </span><span class="wse9">treatment over 1998±2013 (dwar®ng previous</span></div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 ydf ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsea">requirements for pesticide and nitrate removal); DETR assumes only £120 m, but bases this on only 10 of</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 ye0 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws85">28 companies requiring expenditure on <span class="ff2 wseb">Cryptosporidium </span>removal.</div><div class="t m2 x1e h5 y104 ff1 fs3 fc0 sc0 ls2">4</div><div class="t m0 x21 h7 y105 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws88">Pollution incidents are sorted by the EA into three categories. <span class="ff2 ws44">Category 1 </span><span class="ws7">incidents are the most ser-</span></div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y106 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsec">ious and may involve one or more of the following: the closure of a source of water abstraction; an</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y107 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsed">extensive ®sh kill; a potential or actual persistent eect on water quality or aquatic life; a major eect on</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y108 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsee">the amenity value of the receiving water; or the subsequent need for extensive remedial measures to be</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y109 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsef">taken. <span class="ff2 wsf0">Category 2 </span><span class="wsf1">incidents are signi®cant but less severe, and may involve the necessity to notify down-</span></div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y10a ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsf2">stream abstractors; result in a signi®cant ®sh kill; render water un®t for livestock; have a measurable eect</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y10b ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsf3">on animal life in the water; contaminate the bed of the river or canal; or reduce the amenity value of the</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y10c ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws7f">water to their owners or to the general public. <span class="ff2 ws44">Category 3 </span><span class="ws66">incidents are relatively minor and have no sig-</span></div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y10d ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsf4">ni®cant or lasting eect on the receiving water. The EA buys ®sh at a cost of £500±1000 for 1000 1-year</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y10e ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws44">old ®sh, and £900±1900 for 1000 2-year olds. We estimate the 50 Category 1 incidents kill 4000±5000 ®sh</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y10f ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsf5">per incident; the 250 Category 2 incidents each to kill 25±50% of this total; and the 2300 Category 3</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y110 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsf6">incidents to kill 5±10%. These costs, however, include only the restocking of the ®sh that were lost and do</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y111 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsf7">not account for the losses of invertebrates and other aquatic life. The cost of river aeration and labour are</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y112 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws87">also not included.</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y113 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws43">122 <span class="ff2 ws44">J.N. Pretty et al.<span class="_ _2"> </span>/ Agricultural Systems 65 (2000) 113±136</span></div></div><div class="pi" data-data="{&quot;ctm&quot;:[1.801471,0.000000,0.000000,1.801471,0.000000,0.000000]}"></div></div>        </div>            <div class="pdf-page-separator"></div>        <div class="pdf-viewer-page">            <div id="pfb" class="pf w0 h0" data-page-no="b"><div class="pc pcb w0 h0"><div class="bi x0 y114 w3 h10 lazyload" data-bg="profile/Jules_Pretty/publication/222549141/viewer/AS:592440796921856@1518260301360/background/11.png" style="background-size: contain;"></div><div class="t m0 x1e hc y56 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsf8">Eutrophication aects water supply (algae can block ®lters, stimulate bacterial</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y57 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws76">growth, and give drinking water an unpleasant taste), irrigation, ®sheries, naviga-</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y58 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws32">tion, water sports and angling (Mason, 1996; EA, 1998a; Withers and Jarvis, 1998).</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y59 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws40">Between 1989 and 1997, some 3000 freshwater bodies have been aected by algal</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y5a ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsf9">blooms, some of which have caused human health problems, the deaths of sheep and</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y5b ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsfa">dogs, and the closure of water bodies for recreation. Most reservoirs in eastern</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y5c ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsfb">England suer periodically from an inability to treat water owing to<span class="_ _1"> </span>a high con-</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y5d ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4b">centration of plankton, leading to costly closure of treatment works for periods<span class="_ _0"> </span>of</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y5e ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws9c">up to 2±6 months (EA). There are no national data on the costs of eutrophication,</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y5f ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws5c">though the remedial costs in reservoirs alone have been estimated to be £4 m/year</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y60 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsfc">(RCEP, 1996). Marine eutrophication, comprising algal blooms, red tides and</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y61 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws5c">anoxia in deep waters, is also increasingly common, but costs are not estimated in</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y62 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws56">this study.</div><div class="t m0 x0 hf y64 ff2 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsfd">5.1.6.<span class="_ _1"> </span>Monitoring and advice on pesticides and nutrients (1f)</div><div class="t m0 x1e hc y65 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsfe">Costs are incurred by the PSD, VMD, and the EA for monitoring of pesticide</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y66 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsff">residues and nutrients in food and the environment, and for administration of</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y67 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws100">schemes and grants to reduce pollution and for advisory services. The costs are</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y68 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsa1">£5.4 m for pesticide monitoring in food and livestock, and £4.75 m for monitoring</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y69 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws37">pesticides at 2500 surface and groundwater sites.</div><div class="t m3 x2d hd y6a ff1 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2">5</div><div class="t m0 x2e hc y6b ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws101">No data are available on residue</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y6c ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws37">monitoring carried out by supermarkets and food processors. The UK government</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y6d ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws102">also incur £0.55 m costs in providing advice to farmers to encourage the adoption of</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y6e ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws78">more sustainable nutrient and catchment management. Although we<span class="_ _0"> </span>include these</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y6f ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws50">costs in the analysis, it could be argued that an alternative, more sustainable agri-</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y70 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws32">culture, would still incur such monitoring costs.</div><div class="t m0 x0 hf y72 ff2 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws3a">5.2.<span class="_ _1"> </span>Cost category 2: damage to natural capital Ð air</div><div class="t m0 x1e hc y74 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws2f">Agriculture contributes to atmospheric pollution through the emissions of<span class="_ _1"> </span>four</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y75 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws103">gases: methane from livestock, nitrous oxide from fertilisers, ammonia from live-</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y76 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws76">stock wastes and some fertilisers, and carbon dioxide from energy/fossil<span class="_ _1"> </span>fuel con-</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y77 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws54">sumption and loss of soil carbon. According to the National<span class="_ _3"> </span>Atmospheric Emissions</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y78 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws3c">Inventory and the EEA inventory (DETR, 1999b, c; EEA<span class="_ _2"></span>, 1999), UK agriculture</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y79 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4c">annually emits 1.064 m tonnes of methane, 0.098 m tonnes of N</div><div class="t m3 x26 hd y115 ff1 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2">2</div><div class="t m0 x27 hc y116 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsc2">O, 0.278 m tonnes</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y117 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws2d">of ammonia, and 0.75 m tonnes of CO</div><div class="t m3 x2f hd y118 ff1 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2">2</div><div class="t m0 x30 hc y119 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws60">-C (these data do not include a factor for soil</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y11a ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws99">carbon loss). These in turn contribute to atmospheric warming (CH</div><div class="t m3 x31 hd y11b ff1 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2">4</div><div class="t m0 x32 hc y11c ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls5">,N</div><div class="t m3 x33 hd y11b ff1 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2">2</div><div class="t m0 x2c hc y11c ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws104">O and</div><div class="t m2 x1e h5 y11d ff1 fs3 fc0 sc0 ls2">5</div><div class="t m0 x21 h7 y11e ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws105">The PSD pesticide residues monitoring programme took 3000 samples in 1997 (down from 4000 in</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y11f ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws106">1996) from retail outlets, which were subjected to 80,000 analyses, at a cost of £1.7 m (£2 m in 1996;</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y120 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsf2">WPPR, 1997). The VMD tested 39,152 samples of domestic and imported livestock foodstus for residues</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y121 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsd1">through a statutory programme to implement EU legislation, with annual costs of £2.7 m, and in a non-</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y122 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws107">statutory programme funded by MAFF conducted 16,767 analyses on 2547 samples at a cost of £1 m</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y123 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws108">(VMD, 1997, 1998; MAFF, 1998). The EA subjects water to 200,000 pesticide analyses; at 8% of sites,</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y124 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws109">Environmental Quality Standards were exceeded by at least one pesticide (EA, 1998c). The cost<span class="_ _23"> </span>is not</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y125 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws82">recorded by the EA, but assuming similar unit costs as for the PSD, we put the annual cost at £4.75 m.</div><div class="t m0 x18 h7 y126 ff2 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws44">J.N. Pretty et al.<span class="_ _2"> </span>/ Agricultural Systems 65 (2000) 113±136<span class="_ _4"> </span><span class="ff1">123</span></div></div><div class="pi" data-data="{&quot;ctm&quot;:[1.801471,0.000000,0.000000,1.801471,0.000000,0.000000]}"></div></div>        </div>            <div class="pdf-page-separator"></div>        <div class="pdf-viewer-page">            <div id="pfc" class="pf w0 h0" data-page-no="c"><div class="pc pcc w0 h0"><div class="bi x0 y127 w3 h10 lazyload" data-bg="profile/Jules_Pretty/publication/222549141/viewer/AS:592440796921856@1518260301360/background/12.png" style="background-size: contain;"></div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y56 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2">CO</div><div class="t m3 x21 hd y128 ff1 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2">2</div><div class="t m0 x34 hc y56 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws75">), ozone loss in the stratosphere (N</div><div class="t m3 x35 hd y128 ff1 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2">2</div><div class="t m0 x36 hc y56 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsba">O), acidi®cation of soils and water (NH</div><div class="t m3 x37 hd y128 ff1 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2">3</div><div class="t m0 x38 hc y56 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2">)</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y57 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws10a">and eutrophication (NH</div><div class="t m3 x39 hd y129 ff1 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2">3</div><div class="t m0 x3a hc y12a ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws5d">; DETR, 1998b, c; EEA, 1999).</div><div class="t m0 x1e hc y12b ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsc1">Extensive research is underway on the external costs of<span class="_ _0"> </span>these gases (Pearce et al.,</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y12c ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsfe">1996; Eyre et al., 1997; Holland et al., 1999). The ExternE study on the external</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y12d ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws10b">eects of climate change gases includes analysis of impacts on climate change,</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y12e ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws93">health, parasitic and vector borne diseases, sea-level rise, water avail<span class="_ _2"></span>ability, biodi-</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y12f ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws74">versity, and storm, ¯ood and drought incidence (Eyre et al.). It puts the marginal</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y130 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws8f">costs of methane at £263/tonne (range £239±353); of nitrous oxide at £7530/tonne</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y131 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws2b">(range £4267±17,333); and of carbon dioxide (as C) at £63/tonne (range £47±113)<span class="_ _2"></span>.</div><div class="t m3 x38 hd y132 ff1 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2">6</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y133 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws10c">The external costs of ammonia have been calculated by identi®cation of emissions,</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y134 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws9a">changes in exposure/impacts, quanti®cation of impacts, and valuation based on</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y135 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws5d">WTP, using the more conservative VOLY (value of a life year) concept, rather than</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y136 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws2a">the VOSL (value of a statistical life), and indicating an external cost of £17<span class="_ _2"></span>1/tonne</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y137 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsb4">(range £83±259) (Holland et al.). These studies indicate that annual<span class="_ _3"> </span>external costs of</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y138 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws2d">these gases arising from UK agriculture are £280 m for CH</div><div class="t m3 x3b hd y139 ff1 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2">4</div><div class="t m0 x13 hc y13a ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws2d">, £738 m for N</div><div class="t m3 x3c hd y139 ff1 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2">2</div><div class="t m0 x3d hc y13a ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wse0">O, £47 m</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y13b ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws2c">for CO</div><div class="t m3 x2a hd y13c ff1 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2">2</div><div class="t m0 x3e hc y13d ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsfd">, and £48 m for NH</div><div class="t m3 x3f hd y13c ff1 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2">3.</div><div class="t m0 x0 hf y13e ff2 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws3a">5.3.<span class="_ _1"> </span>Cost category 3: damage to natural capital Ð soil</div><div class="t m0 x0 hf y13f ff2 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsbb">5.3.1.<span class="_ _1"> </span>O-site damage caused by soil erosion (3a)</div><div class="t m0 x1e hc y140 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsfe">A healthy soil is vital for agriculture, but modern farming has accele<span class="_ _2"></span>rated ero-</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y141 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws7b">sion, primarily through the cultivation of winter cereals, the conversion of pasture</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y142 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws7b">to arable, the removal of ®eld boundaries and hedgerows, and overgrazing<span class="_ _0"> </span>of ani-</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y143 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsfb">mals on grasslands (Evans, 1995, 1996; RCEP, 1996; DETR, 1997a; EEA, 1998).</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y144 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws10d">Soil erosion causes both on- and o-farm problems.</div><div class="t m3 x1f hd y145 ff1 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2">7</div><div class="t m0 x40 hc y146 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws10d">We do not include internal</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y147 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsb0">costs, even though loss of soil fertility represents a loss of public good in the long-</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y148 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws10e">run. O-site costs arise when soil carried o farms by water or wind blocks</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y149 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws101">ditches and roads, damages property, induces trac accidents, increases the risk of</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y14a ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws10f">¯oods, and pollutes water through sediments and associated nitrate, phosphate and</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y14b ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws110">pesticides. Evans, using data from local authorities, estimates that the national</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y14c ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws111">external costs to property and roads alone to be £13.77 m (£4 m for damage to</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y14d ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws9d">roads and property; £0.1 m for trac accidents; £1.19 m for footpath loss; £8.47 for</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y14e ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws112">channel degradation), but not counting water company costs (see category 1) or</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y14f ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws9b">losses to ®sheries.</div><div class="t m2 x1e h5 y150 ff1 fs3 fc0 sc0 ls2">6</div><div class="t m0 x21 h7 y151 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws113">The data in the Open Framework and FUND models take account of dierences in discount rate, are</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y152 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws114">weighted according to wealth dierences in aected countries, and take account of `social contingency&apos;</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y153 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsd9">(the capacity of regions/countries to adapt to change). This means that uncertainty is still very large (c.f.</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y154 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws115">Eyre et al., 1997). We adopt a conservative ®gure for damage costs based on a quarter of the dierence</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y155 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsf2">between the lowest and highest estimates contained in the Open and FUND models, and according to two</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y156 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws83">dierent discount rates (1 and 3%).</div><div class="t m2 x1e h5 y157 ff1 fs3 fc0 sc0 ls2">7</div><div class="t m0 x21 h7 y158 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws88">Costs incurred by farmers themselves from soil erosion arise from: (1) loss of organic matter leading</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y159 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws116">to decreased water holding capacity of soils and increased run-o; (2) loss of organic matter-rich soils</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y15a ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws117">reduces yields as crops are slower to germinate; and (3) loss of nutrients and crops themselves in water and</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y15b ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws118">wind erosion. Evans (1995, 1996) estimates the annual on-farm costs of soil erosion to be £10±11 m (1996</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y15c ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2">prices).</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y15d ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws43">124 <span class="ff2 ws44">J.N. Pretty et al.<span class="_ _2"> </span>/ Agricultural Systems 65 (2000) 113±136</span></div></div><div class="pi" data-data="{&quot;ctm&quot;:[1.801471,0.000000,0.000000,1.801471,0.000000,0.000000]}"></div></div>        </div>            <div class="pdf-page-separator"></div>        <div class="pdf-viewer-page">            <div id="pfd" class="pf w0 h0" data-page-no="d"><div class="pc pcd w0 h0"><div class="bi x0 y15e w3 h10 lazyload" data-bg="profile/Jules_Pretty/publication/222549141/viewer/AS:592440796921856@1518260301360/background/13.png" style="background-size: contain;"></div><div class="t m0 x0 hf y56 ff2 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsb9">5.3.2.<span class="_ _1"> </span>Organic matter (OM) and carbon dioxide losses (3b)</div><div class="t m0 x1e hc y57 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws119">Soils in England, Wales and Scotland contain some 21.78 billion tonnes of carbon</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y58 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws11a">(Howard et al., 1995; DETR, 1997a; Smith et al., 1998). Arable soils contain on</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y59 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws11b">average 162 tonnes C/ha, permanent pasture 207 tonnes C/ha, and soils under semi-</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y5a ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws11c">natural vegetation 350 tonnes C/ha. Most carbon in the UK is in Scottish peats</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y5b ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws11d">(16.4 billion tonnes alone). Carbon accumulates in soil when arable land is</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y5c ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws11e">converted to grassland or forest, and when sustainable farm practices lead to</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y5d ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws7c">OM incorporation, but it is rapidly lost when pastures are ploughed or when agri-</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y5e ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws119">cultural land is intensively cultivated (Ka</div><div class="t m0 x35 h11 y15f ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls6">È<span class="ls2 ws2e v0">tterer and Andre</span></div><div class="t m0 x41 hc y160 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls7">Â<span class="ls2 ws2e v0">n, 1999). The OM content</span></div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y5f ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws93">in UK soils has declined in recent years (DETR; EEA, 1998; but see Skinner and</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y60 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws32">Todd, 1998, for another view). Soils lose CO</div><div class="t m3 x8 hd y161 ff1 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2">2</div><div class="t m0 x42 hc yf1 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsbe">when OM is lost, and using estimates</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc yf2 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws39">of soil OM loss, we calculate that 20% of arable soils (0.92 m ha) have lost 1.7% or</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc yf3 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws3c">more of OM since 1980, amounting to 1.42 tonnes C/ha/year.</div><div class="t m3 x43 hd y162 ff1 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2">8</div><div class="t m0 x27 hc y163 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws76">Given an external</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y164 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws11f">cost for CO</div><div class="t m3 x44 hd y165 ff1 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2">2</div><div class="t m0 x45 hc y166 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws120">of £63/tonne (range £47±113), this puts the annual cost at £82.3 m</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y167 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws92">(range £59±140).</div><div class="t m3 x46 hd y168 ff1 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2">9</div><div class="t m0 x0 hf y169 ff2 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws56">5.4.<span class="_ _1"> </span>Cost category 4: damage to natural capital Ð biodiversity and landscape</div><div class="t m0 x0 hf y16a ff2 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws3a">5.4.1.<span class="_ _1"> </span>Biodiversity and wildlife (habitats and species) (4a)</div><div class="t m0 x1e hc y16b ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws121">Modern farming has had a severe impact on wildlife: 170 native species have</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y16c ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws46">become extinct this century, including 7% of dragon¯ies, 5% of butter¯ies and 2%</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y16d ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws2a">of ®sh and mammals. In addition, 95% of wild¯ower-rich meadows have been lost</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y16e ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws2a">since 1945; 30±50% of ancient lowland woods; 50% of heathland; 50% of lowland</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y16f ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4b">fens, valley and basin mires; and 40% of hedgerows (DETR, 1998<span class="_ _2"></span>d; Pretty, 1998).</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y170 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws122">Species diversity is also declining in the farmed habitat itself. Draining and fertilizers</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y171 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws123">have replaced ¯oristically rich meadows with grass<span class="_ _1"> </span>monocultures, overgrazing of</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y172 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws103">uplands has reduced species diversity, and herbicides have cut<span class="_ _1"> </span>diversity in arable</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y173 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws39">®elds. Farmland birds have particularly suered: the populations of nine species fell</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y174 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws37">by more than a half between 1970 and 1995 (Campbell and Cooke, 1997; Pain and</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y175 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsbe">Pienkowski, 1997; Mason, 1998).</div><div class="t m0 x1e hc y176 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws124">In this study, we use the costs of restoring species and habitats under the Biodi-</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y177 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws93">versity Action Plans (BAPs) as a proxy of the costs of wildlife and habitat losses.</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y178 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws2b">These plans contain costed targets and action plans for 406 priori<span class="_ _2"></span>ty species and 38</div><div class="t m2 x1e h5 y179 ff1 fs3 fc0 sc0 ls2">8</div><div class="t m0 x21 h7 y17a ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws125">According to the National Soils Inventory (DETR, 1997a), there was an increase between 1980 and</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y17b ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws126">1995 in the proportion of arable topsoils found to have OM concentrations of &lt;3.6% (from 32 to 41% of</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y17c ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws113">samples) and a corresponding decrease in the number of topsoils with &gt;7% OM (from 22 to 11%)</div><div class="t m2 x47 h5 y150 ff1 fs3 fc0 sc0 ls2">8</div><div class="t m0 x28 h7 y17d ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws127">. Thus</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y17e ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws128">with 11% of samples showing OM declines from 7 to 5.3% (mid-range) and a further 11% showing OM</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y17f ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws86">decline from 5.3 to &lt;3%, this gives a value of 20% of soils (assuming these losses occur mainly in arable</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y180 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws129">soils, and that rough and permanent pastures are largely carbon neutral, this suggests losses on 0.92 m ha)</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y181 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws12a">showing OM declines of 1.7% or more since 1980. We therefore assume a loss of soil OM of 1.7% in a 20</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y182 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws12b">cm depth; given a typical dry bulk density of 1.25 g/cm</div><div class="t m2 x48 h5 y183 ff1 fs3 fc0 sc0 ls2">3</div><div class="t m0 x42 h7 y184 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsee">(range 1.1±1.6); and given that approximately</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y185 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws12c">50% of soil OM is carbon (20±75% range), this suggests losses of 21.3 tonnes C/ha over 15 years, or 1.42</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y186 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws61">tonnes C/ha/year.</div><div class="t m2 x1e h5 y187 ff1 fs3 fc0 sc0 ls2">9</div><div class="t m0 x21 h7 y188 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws12d">Under deliberate management for soil OM and carbon accumulation, such as zero tillage and cover</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y189 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsf0">cropping, it is possible for soils to accumulate some 22.8 tonnes C/ha/year Ð a bene®t of £1596/ha/year</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y18a ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws82">(Smith et al., 1998).</div><div class="t m0 x18 h7 y18b ff2 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws44">J.N. Pretty et al.<span class="_ _2"> </span>/ Agricultural Systems 65 (2000) 113±136<span class="_ _4"> </span><span class="ff1">125</span></div></div><div class="pi" data-data="{&quot;ctm&quot;:[1.801471,0.000000,0.000000,1.801471,0.000000,0.000000]}"></div></div>        </div>            <div class="pdf-page-separator"></div>        <div class="pdf-viewer-page">            <div id="pfe" class="pf w0 h0" data-page-no="e"><div class="pc pce w0 h0"><div class="bi x0 y18c w3 h10 lazyload" data-bg="profile/Jules_Pretty/publication/222549141/viewer/AS:592440796921856@1518260301360/background/14.png" style="background-size: contain;"></div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y56 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws12e">key habitats (UK Biodiversity Steering Group, 1995, 1998, 1999; DETR, 1997a,</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y57 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2">b).</div><div class="t m3 x1a hd y18d ff1 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2">10</div><div class="t m0 x1 hc y12a ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws12f">For those species and habitats for which agriculture is identi®ed as one of the</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y12b ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws56">factors causing problems, we have used details in each of the BAPs to estimat<span class="_ _2"></span>e that</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y12c ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws49">half of the costs of actions to protect and restore them can be attributed to agri-</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y12d ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsfb">culture. These plans aim to restore only a proportion of past species and habitat</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y12e ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws56">declines, so they underestimate the cost of biodiversity loss.</div><div class="t m0 x1e hc y12f ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws130">The total costs of plans for species aected by farming practices and partly</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y130 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws78">dependent on farmland is £1.69 m/year (10 vertebrate species £1.25 m; 16 inverte-</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y131 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsb9">brates £0.27 m; and 20 plant species £0.22 m). The average annual cost of a habitat</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y18e ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws36">plan is £2.37 m, which puts the total cost for farmland habitats and habitats aected</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y18f ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws79">by farming practices to be £22.39 m/year. This gives an annual total for both species</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y190 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsb9">and habitats aected by agriculture of £24.6 m.</div><div class="t m0 x0 hf y191 ff2 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws56">5.5.<span class="_ _1"> </span>Hedgerows and drystone walls (4b)</div><div class="t m0 x1e hc y192 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws131">Hedgerows and stonewalls are important for landscape, wildlife and cultural value,</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y193 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws7d">as well as being valuable for soil conservation and stock control, and as habitats for</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y194 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsa9">bene®cial insects and birds. We use the amount that farm<span class="_ _2"></span>ers receive for replacing</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y195 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsaa">hedgerows and drystone walls under agri-environment schemes as a proxy for cost.</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y196 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws132">Net hedgerow stock declined from 563,000 to 377,500 km between 1984 and 1993, an</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y197 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws133">average loss of 18,560 km (DETR, 1997c, 1998d). But taking into account hedgerow</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y198 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws11b">restoration (5700 km/year), the total annual losses are some 24,260 km (only 15% is</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y199 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws2d">due to outright removal, the remainder becoming derelict due to poor managem<span class="_ _2"></span>ent).</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y19a ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws49">Farmers receive £2±4/m to restore hedgerows, putting the cost to restore just one</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y19b ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws33">year&apos;s total loss of 24,260 km to be £72.8 m (range of £48.5±97.0 m).</div><div class="t m0 x1e hc y19c ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws134">Over the past 40 years, 7000 km of drystone walls have been lost from upland</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y19d ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws73">landscapes; 50% of the remaining 112,000 km have become derelict and no longer</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y19e ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws31">stockproof, and a further 46% are in need of some restoration. Assuming a cost of</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y19f ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws135">£16/m for lost stonewalls, £12/m for derelict walls, and £4/m for restoration</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y1a0 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws2f">(restoration grants of £12±16/m are available under the Countryside Stewardship</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y1a1 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws3e">Scheme), then the annual cost is £24.8 m.</div><div class="t m0 x0 hf y1a2 ff2 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws5d">5.5.1.<span class="_ _1"> </span>Bee colony losses (4c)</div><div class="t m0 x1e hc y1a3 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws97">Honey and bumble bees are the most important insect pollinators in the UK,</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y1a4 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wscf">pollinating some 70 crops. There are 200,000 honey bee colon<span class="_ _2"></span>ies in the UK, owned</div><div class="t m2 x1e h5 y1a5 ff1 fs3 fc0 sc0 ls2">10</div><div class="t m0 x34 h7 y1a6 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws136">The BAPs contain some farmland species (e.g. skylark) and habitats (e.g. cereal ®eld margins), for</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y1a7 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsf5">which the costs relate primarily to agriculture. Other species (e.g. song thrush) and habitats (e.g. salt-</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y1a8 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws137">marsh) are partly dependent on farming, or have declined partly as a result of agricultural practices (e.g.</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y1a9 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws138">great crested newt, fens; UK Biodiversity Group, 1995, 1998, 1999). The cost per habitat has been calcu-</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y1aa ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws1f">lated by taking the mean of 1997 and 2000 costings. The habitat plans cover only public expenditure; are</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y1ab ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws139">additional to existing ®nancial commitments; include the costs of managing public sector land, and the</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y1ac ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws13a">costs of land management scheme payments (including administration); take account of revenue from</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y1ad ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws116">land management (e.g. reeds and grazing); include land purchase costs, both the costs of public sector</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y1ae ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws13b">acquisition and grants for private sector purchase; and exclude the costs of research, monitoring, advice to</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y1af ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws13c">managers, site safeguard and designations and publicity. For this study, only habitat management,</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y1b0 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws44">restoration and creation costs are included.</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y1b1 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws43">126 <span class="ff2 ws44">J.N. Pretty et al.<span class="_ _2"> </span>/ Agricultural Systems 65 (2000) 113±136</span></div></div><div class="pi" data-data="{&quot;ctm&quot;:[1.801471,0.000000,0.000000,1.801471,0.000000,0.000000]}"></div></div>        </div>            <div class="pdf-page-separator"></div>        <div class="pdf-viewer-page">            <div id="pff" class="pf w0 h0" data-page-no="f"><div class="pc pcf w0 h0"><div class="bi x0 y1b2 w3 ha lazyload" data-bg="profile/Jules_Pretty/publication/222549141/viewer/AS:592440796921856@1518260301360/background/15.png" style="background-size: contain;"></div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y56 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws11a">by 35,000 beekeepers (of whom only 300 are commercial). Carreck and Williams</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y57 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws39">(1998) put the total annual value of bees at £153.6 m (90% for pollination; 10% for</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y58 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws13d">honey and beeswax) Ð roughly £770/colony (1996 prices). Although bees are</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y59 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws13e">damaged by modern agriculture through exposure to pesticides and the loss of</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y5a ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws69">habitat (e.g. loss of ¯ower-rich meadows), there are no estimates of the costs of bee</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y5b ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws9e">losses</div><div class="t m3 x1c hd y1b3 ff1 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2">11</div><div class="t m0 x2a hc y1b4 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws51">. However, a 1943 study indicated that there were 429,000 colonies (Butler,</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y1b5 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws54">1943), suggesting a loss over 53 years of some 4320 colonies per year. It is impos<span class="_ _2"></span>sible</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y1b6 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws2a">to say how much of this decline is directly due to modern agriculture (the parasitic</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y1b7 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws13f">mite, <span class="ff2 ws140">Varroa jacobsoni</span><span class="ws141">, has killed many colonies, and demand for domestic honey</span></div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y1b8 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws2f">has changed). But as bee keepers are unable to meet the demand<span class="_ _1"> </span>for pollination</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y1b9 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wscf">services (indicating a shortage of bees), we assume that half of the losses are due to</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y1ba ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws3a">modern agriculture Ð some 2160 colonies/year, putting the cost at some £1.73 m.</div><div class="t m0 x0 hf y1bb ff2 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws5d">5.5.2.<span class="_ _1"> </span>Agricultural biodiversity (4d)</div><div class="t m0 x1e hc y1bc ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws142">In addition to the loss of wild biodiversity, agricultural biodive<span class="_ _2"></span>rsity has been</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y1bd ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws143">declining sharply during the course of this century (Fowler and Mooney, 1990;</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y1be ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws144">Heywood, 1995; RAFI, 1997). It is currently not possible to put a cost on these</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y1bf ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws145">losses of genetic diversity, particularly where whole species or varieties are</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y1c0 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws9e">concerned.</div><div class="t m0 x0 hf y1c1 ff2 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsbb">5.6.<span class="_ _1"> </span>Cost category 5: damage to human health Ð pesticides</div><div class="t m0 x1e hc y1c2 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws146">Pesticides can aect workers engaged in their manufacture, transport and dis-</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y1c3 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsa3">posal; operators who apply them in the ®eld; and the general public. Estimates for</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y1c4 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws147">the external health costs of pesticides are almost certainly considerable unde<span class="_ _2"></span>r-</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y1c5 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws2d">estimates, owing to diering risks per product, poor understanding of chronic<span class="_ _3"> </span>eects</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y1c6 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws3c">(e.g. in cancer causation), weak monitoring systems, and misdiagnoses by doctors</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y1c7 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws3e">(Repetto and Baliga, 1996; HSE, 1998a, b; Pearce and Tinch, 1998; Prett<span class="_ _2"></span>y, 1998):</div><div class="t m0 x0 hf y1c8 ff2 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsbb">5.6.1.<span class="_ _1"> </span>Pesticides Ð acute eects (5a)</div><div class="t m0 x1e hc y1c9 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4e">It is very dicult to say exactly how many people are aected by pesticides each</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y1ca ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws70">year. According to voluntary reporting to the HSE, some 100±200 incidents occur</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y1cb ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws148">each year, of which few are substantiated.</div><div class="t m3 x36 hd y1cc ff1 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2">12</div><div class="t m0 x49 hc y1cd ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws148">However, recent HSE research indicates</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y1ce ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws149">signi®cant under-reporting (HSE, 1998a, b). One survey of 2000 pesticide users</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y1cf ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws79">found that 5% reported at least one symptom in the past year and about which they</div><div class="t m2 x1e h5 y1d0 ff1 fs3 fc0 sc0 ls2">11</div><div class="t m0 x34 h7 y1d1 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsf3">The National Bee Unit con®rmed only 82 colonies aected in 1998 out of 200,000. In the USA, the</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y1d2 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws14a">number of honey bee colonies has declined from 5.9 million in 1987 to 2.8 million in 1994. Each year,</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y1d3 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws1f">some 15,000 colonies are aected by pesticides (Ho and Willett, 1995; Nabhan and Buchmann, 1997).</div><div class="t m2 x1e h5 y7d ff1 fs3 fc0 sc0 ls2">12</div><div class="t m0 x34 h7 y7e ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws14b">Fatalities from pesticides at work in Europe and North America are rare Ð one a decade in the UK,</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y7f ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsf6">and eight a decade in California. In the UK, a variety of institutions collect mortality and morbidity data,</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y1d4 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsd0">but in California, where there is the most comprehensive system of reporting in the world, ocial records</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y81 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws66">show that some 1200±2000 farmers, farmworkers and the general public are poisoned each year (CDFA,</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y82 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws14c">1972±current <span class="ff2 ws1e">passim</span><span class="wsd3">; Pretty, 1998). There appears to be greater risk from pesticides in the home and</span></div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y83 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws82">garden where children are most likely to suer. In Britain, 600±1000 people need hospital treatment each</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y1d5 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws7">year from home poisoning.</div><div class="t m0 x18 h7 y85 ff2 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws44">J.N. Pretty et al.<span class="_ _2"> </span>/ Agricultural Systems 65 (2000) 113±136<span class="_ _4"> </span><span class="ff1">127</span></div></div><div class="pi" data-data="{&quot;ctm&quot;:[1.801471,0.000000,0.000000,1.801471,0.000000,0.000000]}"></div></div>        </div>            <div class="pdf-page-separator"></div>        <div class="pdf-viewer-page">            <div id="pf10" class="pf w0 h0" data-page-no="10"><div class="pc pc10 w0 h0"><div class="bi x0 y1d6 w3 ha lazyload" data-bg="profile/Jules_Pretty/publication/222549141/viewer/AS:592440796921856@1518260301360/background/16.png" style="background-size: contain;"></div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y56 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws14d">had consulted a doctor. A further 10% had been aected (mostly by headaches), but</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y57 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws14e">had not consulted a doctor. As some 105,000 farmers hold pesticide certi®cates in</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y58 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws29">Britain, this suggests that at least 5250 farmers suer sucient symptoms to consult</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y59 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws75">a General Practitioner (GP) each year, and a further 10,500 are adversely aected</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y5a ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsba">to a lesser degree. This suggests the annual costs borne by farmers and the health</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y5b ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws14f">system are £1.05 m.</div><div class="t m3 x17 hd y1b3 ff1 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2">13</div><div class="t m0 x39 hc y1b4 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws13e">Strictly, though, these are mostly private costs borne by</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y1b5 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsbe">farmers (except for GP consultations and eects on hired workers).</div><div class="t m3 x4a hd y1d7 ff1 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2">14</div><div class="t m0 x0 hf y1d8 ff2 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsbb">5.6.2.<span class="_ _1"> </span>Pesticides Ð chronic eects (5b)</div><div class="t m0 x1e hc y1d9 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws102">Chronic health hazards associated with pesticides are even<span class="_ _3"> </span>more dicult to assess.</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y1da ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws99">The most controversial issue is whether or not some products are carcinogenic.</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y1db ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws12e">Pesticides are ingested via food and water, and these represent some risk to the</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y1dc ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws150">public. With current scienti®c knowledge, it is impossible to state categorically</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y1dd ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws151">whether or not certain pesticides play a role in cancer causation. In this study,</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y1de ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws102">therefore, we do not include the external costs associated with chronic<span class="_ _3"> </span>health eects.</div><div class="t m0 x0 hf y1df ff2 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsbb">5.7.<span class="_ _1"> </span>Cost category 6: damage to human health Ð nitrate</div><div class="t m0 x1e hc y1e0 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws32">Nitrate is not toxic to humans, though it can be reduced by bacteria in the g<span class="_ _2"></span>ut or</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y1e1 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws49">mouth to nitrite, which is a well-established cause of methaemogl<span class="_ _2"></span>obinaemia (blue</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y1e2 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wscf">baby syndrome), which lessens the capacity of the blood to carry oxygen. Acquired</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y1e3 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws8f">methaemoglobinaemia is most likely to occur in infants in the ®rst few months of</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y1e4 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws38">life, though there have been no cases since the 1950s in Britain. The link between</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y1e5 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws152">nitrate and cancers of the stomach, bladder and oesophagus through the formation</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y1e6 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws12e">of nitrosamines was long suspected to be a health risk, but epidemiological and</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y1e7 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4a">other studies have not yet proven causation. For this study, we assume that nitrate</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y1e8 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws8f">causes no direct external health costs in the UK (nitrate does have to be removed</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y1e9 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws32">from drinking water to meet legal standards Ð see cost category 1b).</div><div class="t m0 x0 hf y1ea ff2 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsbb">5.8.<span class="_ _1"> </span>Cost category 7: damage to human health Ð micro-organisms and other disease</div><div class="t m0 x0 hf y1eb ff2 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2">agents</div><div class="t m0 x0 hf y1ec ff2 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws2c">5.8.1.<span class="_ _1"> </span>Bacterial and viral outbreaks in food (7a)</div><div class="t m0 x1e hc y1ed ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws95">In the UK, the main food poisoning threats arise from <span class="ff2 ws9e">Bacillus</span><span class="ls8">,</span><span class="ff2 ws9e">Campylobacter</span>,</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y1ee ff2 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws9e">Cryptosporidium<span class="ff1 ls9">,</span>Clostridium<span class="ff1 lsa">,</span><span class="ws153">Escherichia coli<span class="ff1 ls9">,</span></span>Listeria<span class="ff1 lsa">,</span><span class="ws154">Salmonella <span class="ff1 wsbf">and Small</span></span></div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y1ef ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws111">Round Structured Virus. According to the PHLS, food poisoning incidents have</div><div class="t m2 x1e h5 y1f0 ff1 fs3 fc0 sc0 ls2">13</div><div class="t m0 x34 h7 y1f1 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws155">Assuming the value of a symptom-day for farmers and farmworkers is £75, and that 5250 farmers</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y1f2 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsf0">are o work for one day, the 10,500 for half a day, and GP consultations cost some £50 each (assuming</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y1f3 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws88">each ill person does go to a GP, and that the cost of illnes is a good measure of WTP).</div><div class="t m2 x1e h5 y1f4 ff1 fs3 fc0 sc0 ls2">14</div><div class="t m0 x34 h7 y1f5 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsdb">The use of organophosphates (OPs) by sheep farmers represents a special case. OPs react with acetyl</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y1f6 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws108">cholinesterase, an enzyme playing a key role in terminating the transmission of nerve impulses. As OPs</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y1f7 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws156">inhibit this enzyme, they can cause continuous nerve stimulation, leading to headaches, giddiness, nausea,</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y1f8 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws13b">blurred vision and rapid heart action. Once again, though, it is farmers and farmworkers who are aected.</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y1f9 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws157">It is now thought that 6000 out of 90,000 sheep farmers are suering ill-health from exposure to sheep dip</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y1fa ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws83">chemicals (MAFF, 1998), putting the private cost of this poisoning at £3.47 m/year.</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y1fb ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws43">128 <span class="ff2 ws44">J.N. Pretty et al.<span class="_ _2"> </span>/ Agricultural Systems 65 (2000) 113±136</span></div></div><div class="pi" data-data="{&quot;ctm&quot;:[1.801471,0.000000,0.000000,1.801471,0.000000,0.000000]}"></div></div>        </div>            <div class="pdf-page-separator"></div>        <div class="pdf-viewer-page">            <div id="pf11" class="pf w0 h0" data-page-no="11"><div class="pc pc11 w0 h0"><div class="bi x0 y1fc w3 ha lazyload" data-bg="profile/Jules_Pretty/publication/222549141/viewer/AS:592440796921856@1518260301360/background/17.png" style="background-size: contain;"></div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y56 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws93">risen sharply in recent years to 94,000/year in 1997 (average of 9000 in the 1950s;</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y57 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws158">6000 in the 1960s; 8000 in the 1970s; 17,165 in the 1980s; and 72,078 in the</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y58 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws10a">1990s; Wall et al., 1996; Evans et al., 1998; PHLS, 1999). However, it is also known</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y59 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws146">that noti®ed cases represent only about 3% of total morbidity (one in 30 cases</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y5a ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws3a">noti®ed) Ð people may suer mild infection, become ill but not seek medical atten-</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y5b ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws32">tion, or be seen by a doctor who fails to notify (Wall et al.).</div><div class="t m0 x1e hc y5c ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws2a">We use reported PHLS data for 1992±1996 on modes of transmission to allocate</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y5d ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws159">costs for food poisoning (Cowden et al., 1995; Djuretic et al., 1996; Evans et al.,</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y5e ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws75">1998). We assume that the 88,000 noti®ed cases (average for 1996±1997) represent</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y5f ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws15a">the tip of 2.64 m cases (at a 30:1 ratio), with 3% noti®ed, 22% consulting a GP, 30%</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y60 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws2f">ill but not seeking medical attention, and 45% with mild symptoms (Wall et al.,</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y61 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsb1">1996). The total costs of all food poisoning (lost wages, consultations with doctors<span class="_ _2"></span>,</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y62 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws6a">hospital beds) are estimated to be £677 m/year.</div><div class="t m3 x2d hd y162 ff1 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2">15</div><div class="t m0 x4b hc y163 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsa0">We conservatively assume that</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y164 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsb1">only 25% of these cases of food poisoning arise directly from UK farming Ð some</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y1fd ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws12e">arise from food processing, from domestic and commercial preparation (such<span class="_ _1"> </span>as</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y1fe ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws8f">from infected food handlers), from consumption of contaminated imported foods,</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y1ff ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws34">and from non-farmed foods such as shell®sh. This puts the annual costs at £169 m</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y200 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsb9">(range £100±243 m).</div><div class="t m0 x0 hf y201 ff2 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws56">5.8.2.<span class="_ _1"> </span>Antibiotic resistance (7b)</div><div class="t m0 x1e hc y202 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws54">Some 1225 tonnes of antibiotics are used in the UK each year Ð 40% for humans;</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y203 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws15b">30% for farm animals; and 30% for domestic pets and horses. Antibiotics and other</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y204 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsb1">antimicrobials are used in modern agriculture for: (1) therapeutic treatment of clin-</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y205 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws3a">ical diseases (20%); and (2) prophylactic use and growth promotion (80% of total),</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y206 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws143">though they are not used in certi®ed organic farming. Concern is growing that</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y207 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsb8">overuse of antibiotics may render some human drugs ineective and/or make some</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y208 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws15c">strains of bacteria untreatable. The World Health Organisation has documented</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y209 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws2d">direct evidence that antimicrobial use in farm livestock has resulted in the emergen<span class="_ _2"></span>ce</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y20a ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws148">of resistant <span class="ff2 ws9e">Salmonella</span><span class="lsb">,</span><span class="ff2 ws9e">Campylobacter</span><span class="lsb">,</span><span class="ff2 ws9e">Enterococci</span><span class="ws15d">, and <span class="ff2 ws15e">E. coli </span><span class="ws2e">types (WHO, 1997).</span></span></div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y20b ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsc2">Some 20±50% of antibiotics used by humans and 40±80% of those used in farming</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y20c ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws32">are thought to be unnecessary (Harrison and Lederberg, 1998; Wise et al., 1998).</div><div class="t m0 x1e hc y20d ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws7a">Evidence shows that some emerging resistance problems,<span class="_ _1"> </span>such as vancomycin-</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y20e ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws15f">resistant <span class="ff2 ws9e">Enterococci</span><span class="ws4b">, are linked to the overuse of antibiotics both in hospitals<span class="_ _0"> </span>and</span></div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y20f ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wse1">on farms (House of Lords Select Committee on Science and Technology, 1998).</div><div class="t m3 x37 hd y210 ff1 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2">16</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y119 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws160">However, it is currently impossible to estimate the external costs of antibiotic overuse.</div><div class="t m2 x1e h5 y211 ff1 fs3 fc0 sc0 ls2">15</div><div class="t m0 x34 h7 y212 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws66">We estimate the costs in the following way: 88,000 noti®ed cases with 1 week o work (at £375 and</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y213 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws161">cost of lost business of £200), of which half are hospitalised see consultants, plus the costs of laboratory</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y214 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws14a">tests on samples, giving £158.4 m. The 580,000 cases that see a GP are o work for 3 days (£225 plus</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y215 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws162">£120), plus GP consultation costs (£50), giving a total of £200 m. The 792,000 cases that are ill but seek no</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y216 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsf6">medical advice are o work for 2 days (£150 plus £80), giving a total of £182 m. And the 1.19 million with</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y217 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws61">mild symptoms miss 1 day (at £75 plus £40), giving a cost of £137 m. The total is £677 m/year.</div><div class="t m2 x1e h5 y218 ff1 fs3 fc0 sc0 ls2">16</div><div class="t m0 x34 h7 y219 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsd2">Vancomycin-resistance is now suspected of being linked to farm use of avoparcin, which was banned</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y21a ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws87">by the EU in 1997. According to the PHLS, one strain of <span class="ff2 ws1e">Salmonella</span><span class="lsc">,</span><span class="ff2 ws88">S. typhimurium </span><span class="ws7">DT104, is resistant</span></div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y21b ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsf2">to at least four antibiotics: it ®rst appeared in the UK in 1990 and now accounts for 15% of all <span class="ff2">Salmonella</span></div><div class="t m0 x18 h7 y21c ff2 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws44">J.N. Pretty et al.<span class="_ _2"> </span>/ Agricultural Systems 65 (2000) 113±136<span class="_ _4"> </span><span class="ff1">129</span></div></div><div class="pi" data-data="{&quot;ctm&quot;:[1.801471,0.000000,0.000000,1.801471,0.000000,0.000000]}"></div></div>        </div>            <div class="pdf-page-separator"></div>        <div class="pdf-viewer-page">            <div id="pf12" class="pf w0 h0" data-page-no="12"><div class="pc pc12 w0 h0"><div class="bi x0 y1b2 w3 ha lazyload" data-bg="profile/Jules_Pretty/publication/222549141/viewer/AS:592440796921856@1518260301360/background/18.png" style="background-size: contain;"></div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y56 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws34">If antibiotic use in farms was to lead to the loss of ecacy of a single human drug</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y57 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws100">per year, then the cost of its replacement would be substantial. The cost would</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y58 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsbd">be very much higher if overuse of antibiotics meant a complete return to a pre-</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y59 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws2c">antibiotic era.</div><div class="t m0 x0 hf y5b ff2 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws3e">5.8.3.<span class="_ _1"> </span>BSE and nvCJD (7c)</div><div class="t m0 x1e hc y5c ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws163">When BSE was ®rst identi®ed in late 1986, research con®rmed that it was a</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y5d ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws74">member of a group of transmissible diseases occurring in<span class="_ _0"> </span>animals<span class="_ _0"> </span>and humans.<span class="_ _0"> </span>It</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y5e ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws15c">appeared simultaneously in several places in the UK, and has since occurred<span class="_ _1"> </span>in</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y5f ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws164">native-born cattle in other countries. By May 1998, 171,598 cases had been con-</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y60 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws79">®rmed in the UK, the epidemic having reached a peak in<span class="_ _3"> </span>1992 (37,000 cases in 1992,</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y61 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4a">falling to 2040 in 1998; NAO, 1998). The link between BSE and nvCJD in humans</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y62 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws119">was con®rmed in 1996, and 35 deaths from nvCJD wer<span class="_ _2"></span>e recorded between 1996 and</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y63 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws122">early 1999. There are still major uncertainties over the possible spread of CJD. Some</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y64 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws165">still contest whether BSE is indeed a causative factor in CJD. It is also not known:</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y65 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws2b">(1) how much BSE-contaminated beef entered the food system and was consumed;</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y66 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws55">(2) the incubation period in humans; (3) the extent of the species barrier between</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y67 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws32">humans and animals; and (4) how the genetic code of individuals makes them<span class="_ _3"> </span>more</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y68 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws166">or less likely to contract the disease. The external costs of BSE have been sub-</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y69 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws2a">stantial, averaging some £607 m for each of 1996 and 1997 (some 49% of the total</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y86 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws32">costs caused by BSE</div><div class="t m3 xf hd y21d ff1 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2">17</div><div class="t m0 x4c hc y21e ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws5d">; Table 2).</div><div class="t m0 x0 hb y21f ff3 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws167">6. Implications for<span class="_ _1"> </span>policy</div><div class="t m0 x1e hc y220 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws168">This study has shown that the total external costs of agriculture in the UK are</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y221 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws6e">substantial, comprising £2343 m, or 89% of average net farm income for 1996. This</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y222 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws2d">aggregate is equivalent to £208/ha/year averaged across all 11.28 m ha of arable land</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y223 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws96">and permanent grassland (but not rough grazings). Pesticide externalit<span class="_ _2"></span>ies are £8.60/</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y224 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsb1">kg of a.i. used in agriculture, and £33/ha of land receiving pesticides. The problems</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y225 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws169">associated with valuing non-market impacts mean that our estimates are con-</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y226 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wscf">servative. The costs incurred in correcting externalities are only<span class="_ _3"> </span>a propo<span class="_ _2"></span>rtion of the</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y227 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws16a">total externalities themselves. In this assessment, some costs also appear low, such as</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y228 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws16b">the eects of pesticides on human health, as their complex behaviour is poorly</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y229 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws5d">understood and so not yet costed.</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y22a ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws16c">food poisoning cases. Other pathogenic bacteria becoming more resistant to antibiotics include <span class="ff2 ws64">E. coli</span></div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y22b ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsb">0157, responsible for the deaths of 20 people in Scotland in 1997. The UK House of Lords Select Com-</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y22c ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws83">mittee on Science and Technology (1998) reported on antibiotic resistance, and concluded that the use of</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y22d ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws44">antibiotics in feed for growth promotion should be banned.</div><div class="t m2 x1e h5 y22e ff1 fs3 fc0 sc0 ls2">17</div><div class="t m0 x34 h7 y22f ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws16d">It could be argued that compensation payments are also a measure of the external costs of BSE Ð</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y230 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws16e">they are a cost to the taxpayer as a result of problems caused by farming. As they aim to cover income</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y231 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws8d">losses as a result of BSE, they could arguably be used as a measure of the net costs BSE has imposed on</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y232 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws129">society (not just a transfer payment). They are an external cost in as much as society as a whole is required</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y233 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsf6">to bear the burden of the costs which the BSE crisis has caused to the farming industry (they have become</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y234 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws82">externalised through public policy). However, for this study, we still leave this outside the framework.</div><div class="t m0 x0 h7 y235 ff1 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws43">130 <span class="ff2 ws44">J.N. Pretty et al.<span class="_ _2"> </span>/ Agricultural Systems 65 (2000) 113±136</span></div></div><div class="pi" data-data="{&quot;ctm&quot;:[1.801471,0.000000,0.000000,1.801471,0.000000,0.000000]}"></div></div>        </div>            <div class="pdf-page-separator"></div>        <div class="pdf-viewer-page">            <div id="pf13" class="pf w0 h0" data-page-no="13"><div class="pc pc13 w0 h0"><div class="bi x0 y236 w2 h12 lazyload" data-bg="profile/Jules_Pretty/publication/222549141/viewer/AS:592440796921856@1518260301360/background/19.png" style="background-size: contain;"></div><div class="t m0 x1e hc y146 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws7c">This study raises several important policy questions. First, how best can ecient</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y147 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsa6">policies be developed to lessen these externalities? Second, which farmed hectar<span class="_ _2"></span>es</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y148 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws16f">contribute the most to externalities, and how can policy eciently target these over</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y149 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws56">farms that are not signi®cant sources of externalities? Third, what are the aggregate</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y14a ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws170">positive externalities provided by agriculture Ð given that these may exceed negative</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y14b ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws38">externalities in some farm systems? As yet, the data is too aggregated precisely to</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y14c ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws6b">answer these questions. And fourth, what are the best approaches to ensure that</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y14d ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws5d">harmed parties are adequately compensated?</div><div class="t m0 x1e hc y14e ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws72">As this paper has focused on the total external costs of UK agriculture, it indicates</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y14f ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws47">the broad policy priorities for reducing total externalities. It highlights the need for</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y237 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsfe">policy reform, and the relative scale of the various external costs<span class="_ _1"> </span>associated with</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y238 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws171">modern agricultural practice. Further analysis of the marginal external costs of</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y239 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws6d">agriculture presents signi®cant methodological challenges, but would<span class="_ _3"> </span>help to inform</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y23a ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws3e">more detailed policy development.</div><div class="t m0 x1e hc y23b ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws2a">In the meantime, a more fair and ecient use of these public resources would be</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y23c ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws172">achieved if policy sought more explicitly to internalise these external costs. This would</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y23d ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws38">imply a redirection of public aid from polluting activities<span class="_ _0"> </span>to sustainable<span class="_ _0"> </span>pr<span class="_ _2"></span>actices,</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y23e ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws70">with subsidies used to encourage those positive externalities under-prov<span class="_ _2"></span>ided in the</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y23f ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws73">market place, combined with a mix of advisory and institutional mechanisms,<span class="_ _0"> </span>reg-</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y240 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws37">ulatory and legal measures, and economic instruments to correct negative external-</div><div class="t m0 x0 hc y241 ff1 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws97">ities. {RGCommons.mountReactWidgetTree({"data":{"publicationFulltextFallbackViewer":null,"publicationUid":222549141,"abstract":"This trans-disciplinary study assesses total external environmental and health costs of modern agriculture in the UK. A wide range of datasets have been analysed to assess cost distribution across sectors. We calculate the annual total external costs of UK agriculture in 1996 to be \u00a32343 m (range for 1990\u20131996: \u00a31149\u20133907 m), equivalent to \u00a3208\/ha of arable and permanent pasture. Significant costs arise from contamination of drinking water with pesticides (\u00a3120 m\/year), nitrate (\u00a316 m), Cryptosporidium (\u00a323 m) and phosphate and soil (\u00a355 m), from damage to wildlife, habitats, hedgerows and drystone walls (\u00a3125 m), from emissions of gases (\u00a31113 m), from soil erosion and organic carbon losses (\u00a3106 m), from food poisoning (\u00a3169 m), and from bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE) (\u00a3607 m). This study has only estimated those externalities that give rise to financial costs, and so is likely to underestimate the total negative impacts of modern agriculture. These data help to identify policy priorities, particularly over the most efficient way to internalise these external costs into prices. This would imply a redirection of public subsidies towards encouraging those positive externalities under-provided in the market place, combined with a mix of advisory and institutional mechanisms, regulatory and legal measures, and economic instruments to correct negative externalities. Further work examining the marginal costs and benefits of UK agriculture would help to inform future policy development.","publicationHeader":{"data":{"title":"An Assessment of the Total External {RGCommons.mountReactWidgetTree({"data":{"publicationUid":222549141,"abstract":"This trans-disciplinary study assesses total external environmental and health costs of modern agriculture in the UK. A wide range of datasets have been analysed to assess cost distribution across sectors. We calculate the annual total external costs of UK agriculture in 1996 to be \u00a32343 m (range for 1990\u20131996: \u00a31149\u20133907 m), equivalent to \u00a3208\/ha of arable and permanent pasture. Significant costs arise from contamination of drinking water with pesticides (\u00a3120 m\/year), nitrate (\u00a316 m), Cryptosporidium (\u00a323 m) and phosphate and soil (\u00a355 m), from damage to wildlife, habitats, hedgerows and drystone walls (\u00a3125 m), from emissions of gases (\u00a31113 m), from soil erosion and organic carbon losses (\u00a3106 m), from food poisoning (\u00a3169 m), and from bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE) (\u00a3607 m). This study has only estimated those externalities that give rise to financial costs, and so is likely to underestimate the total negative impacts of modern agriculture. These data help to identify policy priorities, particularly over the most efficient way to internalise these external costs into prices. This would imply a redirection of public subsidies towards encouraging those positive externalities under-provided in the market place, combined with a mix of advisory and institutional mechanisms, regulatory and legal measures, and economic instruments to correct negative externalities. Further work examining the marginal costs and benefits of UK agriculture would help to inform future policy Challenges and Priorities for Internalizing the Externalities of Modern Agriculture","type":"Article","abstract":"Agriculture is inherently multifunctional. It jointly produces more than food, fibre or oil, having a profound impact on many elements of economies and ecosystems. A comprehensive framework is used to present new data on annual external costs in Germany ( 1.2 billion; US$2 billion), in the UK ( 2.3 billion; US$3.8 billion) and in the USA ( 21 billion; US$34.7 billion). These costs are...","longerAbstract":"Agriculture is inherently multifunctional. It jointly produces more than food, fibre or oil, having a profound impact on many elements of economies and ecosystems. A comprehensive framework is used to present new data on annual external costs in Germany ( 1.2 billion; US$2 billion), in the UK ( 2.3 billion; US$3.8 billion) and in the USA ( 21 billion; US$34.7 billion). These costs are equivalent to 49-208\/ha (US$81-343\/ha) of arable and grassland. Agriculture also produces positive externalities, and though there is no comprehensive valuation framework, the public benefits in the UK appear to be in the range of 10-30 (US$16-49) per household, or some 20-60\/ha (US$32-100\/ha) of arable and pasture land. These external costs and benefits raise important policy questions. In particular, should farmers receive public support for the multiple public benefits they produce? Should those that pollute have to pay for restoring the environment and human health? Policy options available for encouraging behavioural changes are of three types: advisory and institutional measures; regulatory and legal measures; and economic instruments. Three of the most promising options for discouraging negative externalities and encouraging positive ones are: (1) environmental taxes; (2) subsidy and incentive reform; and (3) institutional and participatory mechanisms. The greatest challenge, however, will be to find ways to integrate such policy tools into effective packages that will increase the supply of desired environmental and social goods whilst ensuring farmers' livelihoods remain sustainable.","url":"publication\/227353371_Policy_Challenges_and_Priorities_for_Internalizing_the_Externalities_of_Modern_Agriculture","clickMilestone":"Pzcu-Tqxw4RVOwDinirGD4Q514FssZktzmHvQaadWyFLI9dva-_OTWAfknhAQqnyasA6WF64OHryl3xV9Z-5eP5Bt6dMjhpDqwrmRRzK","publicationFiguresAuthorList":{"data":{"publicationUid":227353371,"totalCount":9,"initialDisplayCount":4,"defaultImages":{"defaultImageSmallURL":"https:\/\/c5.rgstatic.net\/m\/4671872220764\/images\/template\/default\/profile\/profile_default_m.jpg","defaultImageURL":"https:\/\/c5.rgstatic.net\/m\/4671872220764\/images\/template\/default\/profile\/profile_default_m.jpg","defaultImageURL2x":"https:\/\/c5.rgstatic.net\/m\/437738464651637\/images\/template\/default\/profile\/profile_default_l.jpg"},"isLoggedIn":false,"isStatic":true},"clientRenderedOnly":false,"templateName":"publicliterature\/PublicationFiguresAuthorList","templateHash":null,"id":"rgw27_5ae36e5de50c0","widgetUrl":"https:\/\/www.researchgate.net\/publicliterature.PublicationFiguresAuthorList.html?isStatic=1","stylesheets":[],"_isReact":true},"journal":{"abbrev":"J Environ Plann Manag","articleInfluenceScore":null,"catAuthor":"University of Newcastle upon Tyne. food poverty by increasing agriculture sustainability in developing countries","type":"Article","abstract":"We examined the extent to which farmers have improved food production in recent years with low cost, locally available and environmentally sensitive practices and technologies. We analysed by survey during 1999\u20132000 208 projects in 52 developing countries, in which 8.98 million farmers have adopted these practices and technologies on 28.92 million hectares, representing 3.0% of the 960 million...","longerAbstract":"We examined the extent to which farmers have improved food production in recent years with low cost, locally available and environmentally sensitive practices and technologies. We analysed by survey during 1999\u20132000 208 projects in 52 developing countries, in which 8.98 million farmers have adopted these practices and technologies on 28.92 million hectares, representing 3.0% of the 960 million hectares of arable and permanent crops in Africa, Asia and Latin America. We found improvements in food production occurring through one or more of four mechanisms: (i) intensification of a single component of farm system; (ii) addition of a new productive element to a farm system; (iii) better use of water and land, so increasing cropping intensity; (iv) improvements in per hectare yields of staples through introduction of new regenerative elements into farm systems and new locally appropriate crop varieties and animal breeds. The 89 projects with reliable yield data show an average per project increase in per hectare food production of 93%. The weighted average increases across these projects were 37% per farm and 48% per hectare. In the 80 projects with small (<5 ha) farms where cereals were the main staples, the 4.42 million farms on 3.58 million hectares increased household food production by 1.71 t per year. We report on the practices and technologies that have led to these increases: increased water use efficiency, improvements to soil health and fertility, and pest control with minimal or zero-pesticide use. This research reveals promising advances in the adoption of practices and technologies that are likely to be more sustainable, with substantial benefits for the rural poor. With further explicit support, particularly through national policy reforms and better markets, these improvements in food security could spread to much larger numbers of farmers and rural people in the coming
